Award.AwardTitle: Microstructural Foundations of Magnesium Performance: A Data Mining Approach to High-throughput Electron Microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to meet ambitious targets for reduced energy consumption and emissions in modern vehicles, one of the most widely adopted strategies involves the deployment of lightweight structural materials. At less than a quarter of the density of steel, magnesium is a natural contender to replace legacy materials in automotive and other vehicle components. However, despite its desirable physical properties, magnesium accounts for only a small proportion of the make-up of a typical automobile. The reason, in large part, stems from the difficulty with forming the relatively brittle magnesium alloys into complex shapes required for vehicle components. This award supports research into the science underlying micro-scale behavior of magnesium alloys during forming and other deformation operations. By uncovering the relationships between the metal's microstructure and its response to deformation, modified manufacturing processes and improved alloys can be designed to enable widespread use of lightweight magnesium components in vehicular and other weight-sensitive applications. This will be complemented by STEM-oriented outreach activities and external collaborations.

The response of a magnesium component to applied deformation is governed by two atomic-level phenomena: slip and twin activity. Twinning is especially vital to deformation at and near room temperature, due to the difficulty of slip. This project will build upon newly developed microscopy techniques (high-resolution electron backscatter diffraction) to generate snapshots of nano and micro-level structural activity during forming activities. Data mining knowledge extraction techniques will be applied to the resultant huge data sets of twin and slip activity in order to accelerate the discovery of interrelations between microstructure and magnesium deformation mechanics. The data mining will employ a decision-tree type analysis and a neural net approach. The resultant knowledge will be embedded in a meso-scale model of twin / deformation activity as the basis for assessment and design of improved alloys for light-weight structural applications. New insights will emerge into twin development that span various grain-size ranges and critical temperature levels. Key structure parameters will be modeled, including detailed grain-boundary character, accurate local (relative) strain levels, dislocation activity / slip transition temperatures, measures of crystal lattice entropy and other metrics of local heterogeneity. Furthermore, the high-throughput microscopy and data mining advances developed as part of the study will serve as a new framework for accelerated knowledge discovery for constitutive models of deformation in crystalline materials.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project formulated and applied an artificial intelligence framework to accelerate discovery of microstructure-level phenomena that contribute to the properties and processability of lightweight magnesium alloys, suitable for vehicle applications. The research environment was crafted to maximize the educational benefit to students across the educational spectrum, and to increase diversity of participation.

Magnesium alloys present ideal combinations of strength and lightness, to reduce overall mass and increase fuel efficiency in vehicle applications. However, they are notoriously brittle, making them difficult to form into the complex shapes required for car body panels, etc. At the microstructure level (a fraction of the width of a human hair), the granular structure spawns so-called twins (or sub-grains) during deformation that can both help and hinder ductile behavior. It is vital that we understand the nature of this twin-formation process if we are to improve the processability of magnesium alloys. However, twins form at seemingly random locations, and are generally observed after many of them have already formed, rather than being witnessed in their early development stages.

This project applied artificial intelligence to 1. Learn where twins are likely to occur, thus enabling early-life observation of their formation in the microscope, and 2. Mine large amounts of electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) data, using an electron microscope, to reveal characteristics of the alloy structure that induce twin formation. Relationships between grain boundary character and propensity for twin formation and propagation were discovered, and the importance of accounting for chains of twins that form across the sample were highlighted and captured in a suitable model. Correlations between twin activity and local structural features (such as microstructural defects) were extracted using the artificial intelligence framework. These insights have been published and captured in open-source models and tools to aid the scientific and industrial communities in the search for optimal materials and forming processes.

Eleven undergraduate students were mentored by four graduate students during this project, resulting in five major journal papers that were first-authored by undergraduate students, with a total of twelve undergraduate contributions to peer reviewed papers. The recent artificial intelligence paper by one undergraduate has already been cited eight times ? more than twice the average of the top-rated journal.

Two of the undergraduates transitioned to graduate students on the same project, and all have either started graduate education, or are planning on doing so. Three female undergraduate students and two Indian students helped to provide a diversifying influence on the project.

The students also participated in an outreach project to connect with High School students in the local community. Hands on lectures and demonstrations were given, and engineering equipment was donated and introduced into the k-12 coursework. This has helped the local school district to become a leader in terms of providing exposure to practical engineering education.

Furthermore, the multidisciplinary nature of the project engaged the students in collaborations with multiple departments in computer science and engineering at four universities, a national laboratory and at General Motors research lab. Multiple extended visits were undertaken to each of these locations by various students, providing invaluable broadening experiences for the next generation of engineers. Not only are the fundamental mechanisms influencing ductility in lightweight alloys now better understood, but the artificial intelligence framework is in place to accelerate future discovery, and a body of skilled and motivated prospective engineers and academics are prepared to move the science forward.

 


Last Modified: 12/20/2018
Modified by: David Fullwood

Images (1 of )
  • Slice of magnesium AZ31 alloy, imaged at progressively higher levels of applied deformation. The coloring indicates individual grains (crystals), with twins appearing as thin grains in increasing numbers.
    Andrew Orme in Materials Discovery
    David Fullwood
    Magnesium Twin Formation
  • Twins nucleate spontaneously at grain boundaries that separate grains with large orientation differences (grey distribution), but form chains more readily across boundaries with low misorientation angle (brown distribution).
    Ali Khosravani in Acta Materialia
    Copyrighted
    David Fullwood
    Influence of grain boundary character on twin activity
  • Decision tree analysis of the combined influence of strain and microstructural features on twin activity on magnesium AZ31.
    Andrew Orme in Materials Discovery
    Copyrighted
    David Fullwood
    Machine-learning Decision Tree Capturing Twin
